title: Location, Location, Integration
description: ビジネスアドレスと個人アドレスは、通常、明確に文書化されておらず、検証もされていません。これはアフリカの新興国にとって大きなハードルとなっています。

f6_assessments.q0: My personal experience working in Zambia for several months gives me perspective on this proposal. This proposal does specifically address the challenge to drive use and utility of the Cardano Blockchain in Africa. The problem set forward by the proposing team is an excellent use case and would bring value to both users and communities as far as convenience and streamlining interaction with local services. there is no mention of collaboration or interconnection with other Cardano projects.  Attn: VCAs there seems to be a bug on the CA tool for this proposal. the 'open challenge brief' button links to wrong challenge brief.
f6_assessments.q1: While this is an excellent idea worthy of development I do not have confidence that this proposal, as it stands, would be successfully implemented. The proposer has not outlined how he would engage stakeholders (banks, utilities companies and emergency services) to drive adoption. The team, if it exists yet, has not been disclosed. There is no roadmap outlining how the project intends to proceed. I think this project could improve its chance of funding by showing a plan on how they intend to proceed in initial stages. They are asking for a huge sum of money without enough detail on how they plan to proceed. There is no evidence that the team has started this project.
f6_assessments.q2: In this project's definition of success at three months it states 'project set up' but doesn't provide us any metrics to gauge this process. I would like to see some kind of plan by which KPIs can be set and the community can audit progress by. There is no discussion of challenges or risks that the project team expects to come up against. I hope this proposer can work with community members to refine his proposal because the idea is great.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal clearly stated  a problem it wants to address and a potential solution , but what i find hard to understand is how this solves the Physical Address problem.
The proposal stated "We will offer individuals and businesses the possibility to input and manage their addresses on the blockchain (potentially built on top of Atala Prism). " and then afterwards followed with "Front-end entry will be via smartphones but, however, also possible for users which don't own smart phones i.e. entries can be made on behalf of 3rd parties.".These two statements seem to contradict each other as allowing proxy enrolment simply implies a lack of individual control of a physical Address and this is the major population of Sub-Saharan Africans who do not have smartphones.I would have preferred to see an effort towards creating a solution for GSM users instead of proxy enrolment.
Most of Sub-Saharan Africa have very bad leadership and basic utilities like water , electricity, education are not provided due to corruption, the proposal fail to address the potential abuse of the system considering this statement "Access to utility services (esp. water and power) requires mapping and overlapping of plans both from the providers and the consumers. Individuals with identity and location mapped out can be streamlined for access to utility services", does this mean that , individuals which are not onboarded will have to find alternatives to get water and power? .
From the description of the proposed solution, the proposal seem to create more problems than solving the physical addressing problem it highlighted.
The whole proposal feels more like a suggestion than an implementable Solution to a problem.
There is no clear indication that proper research has been made in delivering this solution , An example is in the "Key Performance indicator" section where the proposal stated this "Community Metrics: Cumulative 50% growth of users on the platform up until critical mass is reached." (How will this be achieved?)
This proposal feels rushed and will need more clarity, depth in explaining the the Solution. 
Considering the above few points , I do not agree this proposal can be implemented.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal highlighted some qualifications without any verifiable link.
The lack of clarity in the proposal implementation further shows a lack of expertise on the subject and feels more like a rough draft.
Key Metrics are not useful and appears more like a hint of the project expectations as regards to a true metric , for example "Activity Metrics: Captured as project activity and partly public deliverables from the project."
The requested amount takes 100% of the fund pot without any implementation and consideration for other projects needing funding in this sub-category.
A proper detail of the Proposals implementation will go a long way in making voters make a decision about this Proposals Solution.
Considering the above, i do not agree that the necessary experience and plan to implement this proposal to success is provided.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal  did not provide sufficient information to help audit its progress.
There are no clear timelines or Milestones that can be used to track the progress of the proposal implementations.
Considering the above , i do not agree the proposal provided sufficient information for audit.

f6_assessments.q0:
The challenge faced by so many communities if Africa about getting access to their addresses is real. How to solve that situation? This is the main question, to which this proposal is bringing an answer, which seems to be presented on one aspect of the needed factors in order for the solution to be well implemented.
I think it would be important to have various stakeholders collaborate on this: municipal government, businesses, health sector...so people won't just register their addresses without supporting documents proving their localisation.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers team doesn't specify is composed by how many people, and their background. As the group, they have 20 years on experience in Software and business development. 
Technically' I checked one of the comment that I find very useful and informative to the proposers, being myself not from the tech sector: ''Unless you are going for a completely public ledger…  Why not solve this with W3C Verifiable Credentials, which would not be stored on-chain? A holder would provide a verifiable credential/presentation to a verifier, upon the holder's choosing. VCs might be stored on some encrypted data vault and service if the user doesn't have a smartphone.
If you could find a reliable delivery service and/or trustworthy human notary, that could be used to implement a "proof of address".  See also https://www.reddit.com/r/ethereum/comments/4dt5x6/proof_of_physical_address_a_kyc_oracle/
I would recommend more deep research on what exists already and that could be replicated to adjusted based on particularities.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal solution is vague in terms of outcomes, and the description of the way of solving the challenge raised.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is an excelent example of the basic problems that have the potential of show to the local population the virtues of the tecnology in its role of enhance the quality of the people's life. 

Many mobile parts to put in order, all a social work with the local community and the local government.  The tecnology side and the social side of the project are one-to-one in terms of capital and effort.  The progress will be slow but acumulative.  

So, I like the proposal but, I think that begin with a prototype is the more suitable step to take it on a first phase and inform to the Cardano's community about the advancement of the project.

In consecuence, that points out to a budget more less ambitious inthe same amount of time (6 months according to the proposal).  If the results are positive at the end of the implementation, more capital could be assigned to the project in the next funds. 

In my opinion, a seed has to be plant initially. And well, let's see what will be its growth in the near term.

My reasoning is based on my direct knowledge about the projects which has a considerable social labor itself.  The reality of those type of projects can be an slow progress reality.  However, the work can be done.
f6_assessments.q1:
-  I encounter the definition of the budget too general for give shape to the numbers in my mind.  The mix of plan of implementation an budget in the same subject (item "budget breakdown" of the proposal) is not the better form of description of the proposal's structure.

- The proposal mention relevant skills and experience but not provide sufficient references or links for check of the team that will implement the proposal.  The proposal does not provided specific details about the team in charge of the implementation.    

-	The proposal does not clearly explain technical aspects like architecture, languages or tecnologies crucial for implementation.

-	The proposal has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation.
f6_assessments.q2:
-	The proposal does not provided a roadmap with milestones according to a project with a high social component.

-	The proposal does not present metrics/KPIs the meaurse not only the success, also the natural complications of a technological project with a high social component.

f6_assessments.q0:
Great idea and well-presneted problem and solution with concrete potential use cases. Great name for the proposal. 
The proposal subject well fit the challenge objectives but as noted could have been also part of the Atala Prism challenge)
f6_assessments.q1:
Seems like an experienced and successful entrepreneur. Name and LinkedIn profile would have been good to add. Any other team members?

The 3, 6, 12 months milestones are stated and while the process makes sense they are presented in a generalized way. More details about each milestone will be helpful to understand that the next steps are clear. Also, why do you try to build an interface in the first 3 months for all use cases? Why not focus on 1 or 2 main use cases for the POC? 

The budget does not include many details. It is a relatively high budget and without a clear plan and details, it is difficult to see how feasible it is. For example: Setting up and running training programs: $60.000 USD (24) What does it mean in relationship to the proposal and how it was calculated. 


I worked with many startups (i.e. seedstars.com, givingway.com) and I believe more details are required to evaluate the feasibility of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap for the time frame seems reasonable and progress could be audited although again more details on each deliverable will be helpful.
KPIs are not listed but generally presented. One KPI is presented as "community growth 50% of users on the platforms until critical mass is reached" - what is the number you are aiming to get to? How much time do you forecast it will take you to get there.

Adding risks and challenges would have been important as well, to show you considered various scenarios, especially as it is still early stage. 

It is an area with great potential and many use cases. However, to perform good audibility (track and measure the progress) more details and clear KPIs are required.
